name: LedgerSMB
description:
LedgerSMB is a free integrated web application accounting system, featuring double entry accounting, budgetting, invoicing, quotations, projects, timecards, inventory management, shipping and more ...

The UI allows world-wide accessibility; with its data stored in the enterprise-strength PostgreSQL open source database system, the system is know to operate smoothly for businesses with thousands of transactions per week. Screens and customer visible output are defined in templates, allowing easy and fast customization. Supported output formats are PDF, CSV, HTML, ODF and more.

Directly send orders and invoices from the built-in e-mail function to your customers or RFQs (request for quotation) to your vendors with PDF attachments.
interact_justification:
obtain: https://ledgersmb.org/content/download
provide feedback & contribute : https://ledgersmb.org/community-guide
contribution_justification:
https://ledgersmb.org/community-guide
https://ledgersmb.org/community-guide/community-guide/development
https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/issues
https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/pulls
contribution_requirements_justification:
Our community guide provides information on a number of aspects of the contributions; the URL below provides coding guidelines for each of the languages the project uses.

https://ledgersmb.org/community-guide/community-guide/development/coding-guidelines
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
Each release get at tag. example: https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/tree/1.5.5
And are uploaded to det download site
https://sourceforge.net/projects/ledger-smb/files/Releases/
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/blob/master/Changelog>.
test_invocation_justification:
Every commit start a new test build 
https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/pull/2673
test_most_justification: Work in progress. The goal is 100%
warnings_justification:
We use the Perl pragmas "use strict;" and "use warnings;"; additionally we use additional Perl::Critic  syntax checks.

As for our JavaScript, we compile our code using UglifyJS which does a syntax check on the code as well.

For our HTML code, we use a linter tool too.
warnings_fixed_justification: Each of our linter tools generate build time failure when there's a policy breach. There's no way to submit code to the project which fails a policy breach due to the use of Travis CI to validate all changes before as well as after accepting them into the code base.
warnings_strict_justification: The project has set out to gradually add stricter checks to e.g. Perl::Critic with each minor release.
crypto_keylength_justification: Encryption of network traffic is off-loaded to a reverse proxy. There are enough FOSS projects to allow users a choice to adhere to these standards.
crypto_working_justification: As the reverse proxy setup is off-loaded to other projects, there's no explicit dependency on cryptographic algorithms; as such, there's no dependency on broken algorithms either.
crypto_pfs_justification: As the reverse proxy setup is off-loaded to other projects, there's no explicit dependency on cryptographic algorithms; as such, there's no means to NOT support forward secrecy in our software.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Storing of passwords is off-loaded to PostgreSQL, which means that the application itself can't either be compliant or non-compliant.
crypto_random_justification: The application doesn't use cryptographic algorithms or keys.
delivery_mitm_justification: The project uses both digital signing, cryptographic hashing as well as https for the software distribution.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The cryptographic hashes and signatures are delivered over HTTPS (the hashes in the release announcements posted on https://ledgersmb.org/ and the signature on https://download.ledgersmb.org/ )
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Multiple rules in the Perl::Critic scanning of the sources are included on advice of security experts.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: All findings from the Perl::Critic scanner must be fixed ASAP.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not includes software written using a memory-unsafe language.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: As the reverse proxy setup is off-loaded to other projects, there's no explicit dependency on cryptographic algorithms; as such, there's no dependency on algorithms with serious weaknesses either.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
Every commit start a new test build 
https://github.com/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB/pull/2673
https://coveralls.io/github/ledgersmb/LedgerSMB?branch=master
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
crypto_used_network_justification: The software can be used with HTTPS (SSL) The web / proxy server is responsible for the SSL communication
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: The web / proxy server is responsible for the TLS communication
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: The web / proxy server is responsible for the TLS communication
hardened_site_justification: One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing. // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
implementation_languages: Perl, SQL, HTML, Tex/LaTeX, CSS, JavaScript
bus_factor_justification:
Output of the truck-factor tool  https://github.com/mtov/truck-factor
TF = 2 (coverage = 23.25%)
TF authors (Developer;Files;Percentage):
Chris Travers;553;65.60
Erik Huelsmann;462;54.80
coding_standards_enforced_justification: The project has set out to gradually add stricter checks to e.g. Perl::Critic with each minor release.
build_standard_variables_justification: LedgerSMB do not build native binaries. https://ledgersmb.org/technical-documentation
build_preserve_debug_justification: LedgerSMB do not build native binaries. https://ledgersmb.org/technical-documentation
build_non_recursive_justification: LedgerSMB do not build native binaries. https://ledgersmb.org/technical-documentation
build_repeatable_justification: LedgerSMB do not build native binaries. https://ledgersmb.org/technical-documentation
installation_development_quick_justifica:
The quickest way to get the Docker image up and running is by using the docker-compose file available through the GitHub repository at:

https://github.com/ledgersmb/ledgersmb-docker/blob/1.5/docker-compose.yml
updateable_reused_components_justificati: 2. use the standard components provided by the system or programming language
implement_secure_design_justification: The application have fail-safe defaults. The  data storage and user access are managed by the database server (PostgreSQL). It is not part of the LedgerSMB application.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The  data storage are managed by the database server (PostgreSQL). It is not part of the LedgerSMB application. PostgreSQL support multiple cryptographic algorithms. https://www.postgresql.org/about/
crypto_credential_agility_justification: The  authentication credentials are managed and stored by the database server (PostgreSQL). It is not part of the LedgerSMB application. https://www.postgresql.org/about/

name: pump.io
description: Social server with an ActivityStreams API
sites_https_justification: Main website is using GitHub Pages with a custom domain. Given an http: URL. // Given an http: URL.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Documentation is in-repo (e.g. https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/blob/master/API.md), in the wiki (https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/wiki), and at ReadTheDocs (https:///pumpio.readthedocs.org).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification:
While pump.io has been upgrading dependencies each and every non-patch release has included security fixes and enhancements which _all_ admins MUST apply. Direct security enhancements were documented, but not fixes pulled in by dependency upgrades.
Once dependencies are up-to-date, the project will announce all future security vulnerabilities.
report_process_justification: https://github.com/pump-io/pump.io/issues or via email to alex@strugee.net.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Information is available on wiki, but not on public site.
test_most_justification: Test suite coverage is comprehensive for server-side code; clientside coverage is planned.
know_secure_design_justification: The primary maintainer, AJ Jordan, has a sufficient understanding of security.
crypto_password_storage_justification: pump.io uses a well-known bcrypt module for password handling.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: pump.io uses Content Security Policy and several other security-related HTTP headers. It also ships with a systemd service which disallows many harmful behaviors in case of compromise. There are plans to make it run in a chroot jail and to improve the Content Security Policy.
crypto_used_network_justification: HTTP will be used if the admin does not configure HTTPS or if activities are distributed to remote nodes whose admins haven't configured HTTPS. There are plans to automatically manage HTTPS and to disallow HTTP activity distribution, and to turn these options on by default.
hardened_site_justification: GitHub meets this criteria. npm downloads do not require these headers. X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: pump.io is distributed as an npm package.
documentation_current_justification: Documentation changes are made in tandem with code changes.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities reported except by NodeSecurity's automated scanner, which were in dependencies
build_preserve_debug_justification: pump.io is written in Node.js; the build system for the template files that pump.io uses does not automatically support debug flags like these. It can be passed a CLI flag, however, by modifying package.json.
installation_standard_variables_justific: pump.io does not install things outside of npm's standard installation directory.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: pump.io rarely vendors libraries and assumes security responsibility for them when we do. Normal workflows are done through npm.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: pump.io uses Travis CI to run its test suite.
